23534509.review:
I'm enjoying this game quite a bit.  The key skill in this game is visualizing and manipulating objects in 3d space, and arranging all the inputs in the assembly process in proper orientation and sequence to complete your project.  Some of your tools are conveyer belts, pushers, sensors, welders, rotators, elevators, and demolishers, and I know there are some more, but I'm only 31 hours in so there's a couple blank tools I haven't seen yet.  Up to this point I've eagerly approached each puzzle, and only really had a couple major setbacks that required complete rebuilds.  You are able to optimize on different vectors including speed, # of parts used, and something else that I can't recall presently ;-)

Compared to Zachtronics game Spacechem (which I also enjoyed), I think the puzzles in this game play out in a bit more "fun" way than the puzzles in Spacechem.  In Spacechem I found myself staring at the screen trying to find a devise a solution for a long time - and then "bang" the moment of enlightenment would come.  Infinifactory is different in that its more a series of small steps that gradually lead you to completion, although you do have to plan holistically the entire way.  The third dimension also provides interesting flexibility in builds also.

The levels are beginning to get a bit difficult for me - I've stalled out on one of the meat preperation levels (the one with the whale) - and this is the first one that I've been hesitant to go back to because the solution looks a bit messy to me so far, it's sortof difficult to see what's happening,  and I have to carefully plan out my cuts on paper to maximize yield.  It's the first level that I haven't been drawn back to so far, but I'll get back to it soon enough.

Anyhow, yes I recommend this game.  It's one of the best puzzle games I've played.   My one suggestion is that I wish there was a straightforward way to insert a logical "AND" into the sensors to require multiple conditions to be true before an action is carried out.  That can be overcome vie less straightforward means usually dependent upon timing, but its seems in several places I was wishing I could insert an "AND" condition and not worry about it so much.

Yes, I recommend this game.

23500322.review:
I got this on May's humble bundle and was intrigued by it...ironically enough [i]despite[/i] it being by the makers of Spacechem. You see...I didn't like that game. It had potential, but had lots of things dragging it down. And with the premise here being somewhat the same but in 3D (take this input and build this), I was cautious: would this suffer the same fate?

I can be blunt: absolutely not. Infinifactory is IMHO much, MUCH better. In what way? I'm glad you asked... :-)

-despite it being 3D, building and placement is intuitive and straightforward. There's a minimal time between the "I want to build [i]this[/i]" and actually placing it. At first I thought this game would work better in an isometric perspective (think the first rollercoaster tycoons), but I'm not sure anymore. In any case: it works for the use you want to make of it.
-much more aesthetically pleasing, even to the point of too much. Someone certainly had fun creating beatifull skylines and wide open floating space platforms. Why are we building a production line of missiles on a sharp mountain top? No reason other than "Because We Can!!!". But hey: video game.
-nice soothing music. And for puzzle games like this, this is a huge plus.
-decent difficulty. In spacechem, I felt like being thrown into the deep water soon after the intro levels. Thus far, the difficulty progresses much better (though don't kid yourself: levels remain challenging)
-interface is clean and simple
-perhaps due to things already mentioned, but I really feel like "just doing stuff" in this game. I like to try, see what works and even love to see how my own best-laid plan turns out completely wrong due to me not understanding e.g. how conveyor belts handle larger block chunks. There's no one single solution, but this game enables you to just trow things at the wall and see what sticks. :-)

On the story, I'm not completely sold. Despite audio logs and occasional performance reviews by aliens who captured you, I just don't feel really engrained in it. It's in no means bad and occasionally funny, it just doesn't connect to the actual gameplay. Then again, there are hardly games you play just for the story to begin with. ;-)

I could name a few other nitpicks (like no toggle fast(er) forward button, or the jumping which is useless with infinite jetpack ammo), but that would only distract from the message that this is an absolutely great puzzle game.

23369397.review:
Infinifactory may be the finest puzzle game I've ever played. It presents you with a simple input/output problem to solve, and gives you tools to solve it. And while the game starts you out with basic routing problems, it eventually has you creating complex production lines that require multiple actions to run harmoniously in parallel. The challenge is in how you abstract and breakdown the problem in to managable pieces, which is vastly more similar to most kinds of real-world problem solving than what is presented by most puzzle games.

And I think that's part of the satisfaction that Infinifactory provides, is that it tests applicable problem solving -- it stretches your brain, creatively, and not just on arbitrary game logic (though, let's not kid ourselves, this is not a "realistic" game).

On top of the really excellent puzzles, Infinifactory is also coupled with an absurd but engrossing little narrative, presented (at first) through mostly environmental details. It leaves you scouring each area for audio logs for a little more insight -- and when that reaches a natural plateau, things really take off.

Infinifactory is truly masterful gamedesign; a must play.

I stumbled on the game randomly on my monthly humble bundle, and when I saw the Zachtronics stamp on it I knew it was going to be good, and yeah i was not disapointed. It's essencialy Space Chem meets Minecraft. 

I'm not too far into the game and the puzzle are starting to get tough, the though process to solve each puzzle is really rewarding, thinking  how to build the differents bits of the target piece, making a quick proto, then integrating it in the chain,  synch with the other line, weld together and BAM!  level is done! No wait I'm sure I can tune a bit to save blocks, or footprint.
And all of a sudden you have the breakthrough about that previous puzzle you solved in a wonky way, you want to go back to redo it with this new elegant chunk of production line that avoids that very long winded triple rotation and pushing module you were proud of but was, admit it, massively ineficient.

The handling is A-OK, it works, does what it says on the tin but sometimes the ergonomy is not as good as it can be. 

The efforts for the story telling are nice, small "easter eggs" etc. 
As for most Zachtronics puzzle the difficulty increase quickly, so don't get scared once you finish the tutorial.

I wish there was a way to capture in game video / sharing on social media, some pieces of machinery are just so satifying I wish I could show them around.

22973802.review:
Infinifactory is the best puzzle game I have ever played, bar none. Period. In my opinion, a good puzzle needs to meet three conditions:

1. It must require hard thinking to solve 
2. It must not be frustrating when no immediate solution can be found
3. it must make you feel smart when a solution IS found. 

The first point is pretty obvious, since most people play puzzle games  in order to think. point 2 is the reason I don't like puzzles as a genre; almost all puzzles can only be solved in one exact way, and if I am not thinking in the super unorthodox and particular way the author deems to be correct, I cannot solve it, and that is frustrating to me. Point 3 is the most important. I can accept some frustration if I end up feeling good when I finallly solve the puzzle. However, again almost all puzzles I have tried make me feel like an idiot for not seeing the solution quicker, when in fact the solution was by design arbitrary and for the lack of a better word, "stupid".

Enter Infinifactory. 1. Infinifactory is hard! I have sat at a single puzzle for literally 3 hours scratching my head trying different solutions only to be foiled by something. It requires three-dimensional visualization and thinking. It requires both hard thinking and creativity in order to solve. 

2. The aforementioned puzzle I tried for 3 hours didn't feel like 3 hours. I decided to play the game for 20 minutes one night before bed, and 3 hours later I realize it has not been 20 minutes. I then continued for another 3 hours (I didn't need sleep *cough*). Infinifactory lets you constantly make progress towards a solution, even when I largely have to start over and delete what I did. It does this by naturally building off of previously done things, and requiring you to combine many small solutions into a coherent whole. 

Finally, 3. Infinifactory makes me feel like a ****ing mastermind mechanical engineer and PhD in quantuum mechanics that just solved nuclear fusion when a factory I built works and works beautifully. I have  never rage quit this game once, since even failing is fun. Seeing the factory being built as it becomes more and more complex is satisfying and inheritantly lets you want to continue and not get frustrated. I would recommend this at 5x the price. 

TL;DR: It is fun to struggle to a solution even when it takes hours to get there.

22922148.review:
Infinifactory is, at it's core, a simple problem solving game. You must get blocks from point A to point B in a specific configuration. It's your job to figure out how to do that with the blocks given. Creating assembly lines that will move your pieces around and assemble them into the finished product. 

If you like puzzle games, and enjoy building things, then this is a game you would likely enjoy.  Construction is reminicent of minecraft and other sandbox block building games, with a lot of trial-&-error required to get to the solutions. 

Pros:
   -Fun, unique, and clever. Well designed game
   -Promotes thinking outside the box
   -Easy to learn, hard to put down
   -Steam Workshop, so you can pit your brain against other people's creations

Cons:
   -The "campaign" is a bit short and completed easily
   -Often a single solution works for most puzzles with a littlte tweaking
   -Puzzles weren't as challenging as I had hoped. Looking forward to playing with community content.

Overall, I'd give the game an easy 8/10 for fun, unique, puzzle play.  If you like puzzle games and block building sandbox games, buy this. It's a great sort of fusion of the two.

I hope to see further development of this game, adding more challening puzzles and other fun and silly rewards to decorate my little hole in the wall. 

Also, please add additional flavours of food pellets. A diverse and delicious meal breeds productivity!

[h1]A Sandbox Puzzle Game[/h1]
https://youtu.be/UJgDlAW4PsA
+ Extremely fun gameplay / puzzles to solve, essentially you are a builder who's job is to build assembly lines to combine and transport various materials for some mysterious alien race
+ A large variety of blocks that completely change the way you solve scenarios. (conveyor belts, welding blocks, pushing blocks, sensors, etc.)
+ Interesting lore / story elements, essentially you are abducted by aliens and assigned to work for them. Many other people were apparently abducted in the past and died,  you can listen to audio logs which explain more about what's going on. 
+ Challenging but very rewarding to see your fantastic contraption come to life and  accurately solve the puzzles
+ Visually the game looks great with some breathtaking backgrounds
+ Great relaxing soundtrack

- I wish more was explained early on, and I wish it would show you what you were making or delivering and why.
- Later on when new blocks are given to you to use, there's a very vague board that shows you how to use them. I wish there were descriptions under each one that told you what each did as it can sometimes be confusing as to how to use each one.

22853287.review: This puzzle game is all about assembling, manipulating and delivering blocks in the right way to their destination. To accomplish this you will set up increasingly complex networks of fully automated conveyor belts accompanied by blocks that weld, rotate and more. The real fun lies in that you get to see how well your friends as well as everyone else who played did, giving you an incentive (beyond that of certain achievements) to keep optimizing your solution. The first person view and 3D environment really call on your spatial thinking. While the earlier levels can be done relatively fast as soon as you get the mechanics, the later levels will have you break down problems into little steps and iterate upon your work as you go. And as you advance you also get to know more of the story you got thrown into.

22786545.review:
Zachtronics is the king of puzzle games. Although Infinifactory is a lot easier than their Spacechem or TIS-100 games, it's still a lot of fun and there are plenty of interesting and challenging puzzles to solve.
It's really rewarding seeing your factories grind out products after building them up from scratch. And there's new mechanics introduced in practically every world, which keeps things fresh the whole time. And the steam workshop integration means there's practically endless puzzles to play.

If I had one complaint it would be that there's no way to increase the fast-forward rate. You need to test often, but there's a lot of downtime holding the F button, waiting for your factory to play to the point you need to actually test. This is only really a problem in the later levels though.

Overall, I highly recommend it.

TL;DR: Not as good as SpaceChem, but still a fairly good puzzle game.

Mainly my problem with Infinifactory is that most of the puzzles just seem too straightforward.  In SpaceChem you had to worry about running out of room to place down instructions, and making sure the waldos could loop properly.  In Infinifactory you just have to make sure things get done reliably and the parts don't get in the way of eachother.  You won't even have a problem with the latter issue in most puzzles unless you increase the speed.  Most puzzles are not complicated enough to even have to think hard about how to get things done.

The plot is alright, but it likewise seems a bit too straightforward.  In SpaceChem you had huge plot twists, escalation, and the feeling of being some kind of secret super-chemist fighting against an unknowable foe.  In Infinifactory, it just feels like you're doing your job.

One of my new favorite puzzle games.  You place down conveyor-belts, welders, and other tools to create machines which build things for you.  As the game goes on, new tools unlock (rotators, lasers, etc) and the objectives become increasingly more complex.

The game is not multiplayer, but there is a multiplayer-component in that the game shows the "blocks used", "space used", and "best time" of the solutions for each of your friends.  My friends and I had even more fun competing to optimize the solutions to the earlier puzzles than we did actually playing the rest of the game.

If you enjoy building giant automated mining machines in the Minecraft mod "Feed The Beast"; or building robots with Lego Mindstorms; or optimization puzzles like [url=http://www.pathery.com]pathery.com[/url], you will probably enjoy this game.

20447555.review:
This is an amazing puzzle game. The building blocks you have are simple with no special tricks, yet you can build some very elegant yet complex solutions to each puzzle.

Each puzzle gives you a rating comparing how you've done with everyone else who's done the puzzle too on a nice bell curve. The farther to the left on the curve you are, the better. There are three different metrics too (cycles aka time, blocks used, and footprint (how much horizontal space your blocks and the materials need to move to reach the goal). All of these metrics are only governed by what you've built, so you are free to try to improve your score, and often improving one score may come at the expense of another. However you have space for three different solutions to each puzzle so you can try multiple approaches to try to improve your best score in different areas.

The game feels like programming/engineering where you need to test your creations at each step of the way to make sure that they are behaving as you expect as well. You can adjust some input parameters like how often materials are provided to you (and at various speeds different materials may come out at different rates, changing how you need to build your solution).

If you liked Spacechem (by this same developer) you'll love this game!

20400002.review:
Like SpaceChem, this is a puzzle game that implicitly allows you to choose how much you want to challenge yourself.

Normal difficulty is just trying to solve every puzzle in any way that works, which, for those who haven't tried Zachtronics designed based puzzlers before, can still be a challenge.
Hard difficulty is when you start itching to find an elegant solution that doesn't have a giant snarl of pushers and sensors each trying to fix some unfortunate stall or collision that popped up the first time you built a solution.
Obsessive difficulty is when you decide you want to find a "best" solution that absolutely minimizes cycles or size with no waste. Even some of the tutorial levels turn in diabolical puzzles at this level. If you go here, you will dream Infinifactories after hours of fiddling. You may even start scouring the web to see if someone somehow did it better (which will, most likely, make you cry or curse profusely). You can, quite frankly, devote as many hours of your life to this game as you wish to without running out of mental challenges if you set the bar high.

Rarely will you ever find a puzzle game that has the depth to admit such rewards from obsessive analytical thinking, if you are the sort of person for whom that holds any appeal.

20307265.review:
Do you like puzzles? Do you like SpaceChem? Do you like MineCraft (appropriate give Zachtronics' Infiniminer being its forebear)?

Then you'll love Infinifactory. It's like SpaceChem, but in 3D, and yet surprisingly accessible. You'll be building crazy 3D contraptions with ease. If anything I'd say it's a fair bit easier than SpaceChem, given a larger working space and lack of meta maps where you need to string together multiple machines. And there's no boss fights.

The plot is a lot simpler here, but it's a case of a little doing a lot. Maybe even more than the creator expected, in that it leaves a lot up to you to interpret and question. It also has a few surprises up its sleeve. The progression of things you create is also a big part of this - from mundane to the militarstic.

I haven't finished every puzzle yet, but whilst a few may initially look daunting, a bit of thinking usually reveals a solution. You'll also learn new techniques as you go (many you'll invent yourself), and some will also be revealed that open up new avenues of production line efficiency. I don't find myself ever really stuck. Break a big problem down into smaller parts and work on those. Then you'll realise, oh wait, you need to refactor this bit because of some reason. And when you finally figure it out, it's really rewarding.

Great soundtrack and nice, simple, effective graphics (and some quite interesting environmental design later) contribute well to the overall game.

Highly recommended :)

在a站看王老菊的视频入坑的。

作为一个码了10年以上的年迈的程序员（是的，我初三就开始码代码了），这个游戏最初给我的感觉就是惊艳。
从输入到输出，一步步构思如何移动、拼接、切割一个个小方块，调试和优化流程，本质上就是编码的过程。

作为解谜类游戏，这个游戏的难度和难度梯度设计我给满分。
从前几关入门教学，到后面的各种不同功能逻辑的综合运用，再加上每次解决关卡后的步数 脚印数 方块数分布图（刺激我过了关还要继续做优化），如果这还不够，还有创意工坊上的各种BT关卡。
不过缺点也很明显，不过对于解谜类游戏无伤大雅：
画面太差了，2015年的游戏感觉连10年前的半条命2都不如，有点说不过去。
背景音乐我是关着玩完的。
再吐个槽：
不知道为什么没有方向朝上的逻辑块和焊接块，有的时候5个方向用满了就会有这个怨念。

总评：9/10

20236414.review:
Starts off easy and increases in complexity at a good pace. You can solve each level however you like, but one of the most satisfying things is trying to figure out the most efficient way to build your machines so they work faster or use fewer components.

After you complete a puzzle, you can compare your efficiency scores with other players, which adds a competitive element. It's fun to go back to levels you've already beaten and optimize everything as much as you can. You might even want to search up videos of other people's solutions to see how they approached a problem differently - then you can incorporate their designs into your own solutions and try to come up with something even better.

Alternatively, sometimes it's fun to build a Rube Goldberg machine for a more convoluted solution that just looks cool.

Amazing game and well worth buying.

20067469.review:
I really like the pacing and style of these puzzles. The easy early ones give you a chance to develop generalized techniques to apply to the later ones, as it should be in a good puzzle game. Unlike some games, the puzzles don't rely on "gotchas" that only the developer would think of (i.e., I've been able to solve all of them without spoilers so far).

The levels tend naturally to break down into clearly divided sub-puzzles, so it's easy to jump in and start making progress. But you won't get bored, as there are frequent twists that can wreck your initial plans and make you consider a reset; sometimes the pieces don't fit together as you expected. When a new mechanic is introduced, expect to spend some time figuring out the nuances. Best of all, as you solve the sub-puzzles of a given level to your liking, your sub-solutions will play and re-play in the background as you continue working on the remaining pieces, which can be oddly satisfying. The score statistic histograms add some replay value for optimization.

You can't die. Timing matters for machines but not player actions. Small mistakes are easily fixed for no penalty. The UI is nicely polished. There's a darkly comedic backstory that intrigues without getting in the way (warning, includes mentions of harm to animals). It's got very well thought out voxel editing tools (I never expected to see a usable drag and drop in 3D). It might be my ideal puzzle game, and it's making me want to try Infiniminer.

19987642.review:
One of the best puzzle games I've played. You essentially create a machine out of blocks/parts that each do a different thing, one block might be a conveyer belt while another is a sensor that can be connected with yet another block that pushes blocks in front of it whenever the sensor activates.

The mechanics of the game are simple and very easy to understand. But to create a machine that produces the goal product can be very hard and requires both logic and intelligence. You will feel very rewarded once you finally succeed. But don't think it is over yet, you will be scored and compared to other players based on how small your machine is, how fast it can build and how many parts/blocks you used for it. You will feel an urge to go back and improve upon it if your score is not to your satisfaction.

Due to the nature of the game it means that for each puzzle there's basically an endless amount of solutions. This gives you a lot of freedom which many other puzzle games lack. In fact, you can save up to 3 machines for each puzzle, this way you can experiment with your current machine without losing anything, you can even try and optimize it for production while neglecting its size and parts.

I'll definitely recommend you pick this up if you enjoy puzzles and logical thinking.

19927343.review:
Where for some reason I could not into Spacechem, Infinifactory has got me by the short and curlies. It's a genius example of puzzle design, really, in a style somewhat reminiscent of The Incredible Machine. You're given a specific input and output, sometimes a few special pieces in the middle, and set loose to design your madcap assembly line. There's no right answer, just whatever produces the desired product without causing a broken pileup along the way. You are then given a numeric breakdown of your carbon footprint, blocks used, and cycles (length) taken, on a bar graph showing average global player scores for that level. I think that's also brilliant, because you aren't competing for any specific "S Rank" conditions (although there are some achievements to that effect), you're just shown how you stack up to the player average and left to decide for yourself if you want to try to go back and optimize things just that little bit more...

Levels often look daunting at first glance, but as prodded at will usually unravel gradually as you work out where to put piece buffers, delay gates, and so on. Failing that, you can always go look at some other player builds, which in recreating you will come to understand the fundamental components thereof. Even by cheating you're learning to play the game better.

There's also a more sandboxy set of levels available, and a built-in GIF recorder for showing off your solutions. Fantastic puzzle game that basically does everything right.

19792673.review:
Infinifactory is the most enjoyable puzzle game I've played in ages

The premise is fairly straight forward, you have one or more input hoppers that provide you with a steady stream of different blocks, which you must then manipulate, assemble and transport to produce a finished product, using a variety of tools such as conveyors and rotators to move them, welders and cutters to join or split them and sensors and pushers to act as basic logic.

Sound simple? In theory perhaps but in practice it's devious, dastardly and downright mind boggling at times. There are many ways to approach each puzzle, forcing you to think laterally and often creatively about how you'll tackle it. I've been taking it slowly, doing one or two puzzles a night and my brain has been loving every minute of it. As the levels progress the puzzles become more complex, forcing you to think up new and better ways to perform parts of the overall task, and gradually increasing your arsenal of available tools to do it with.

What really puts the icing on the cake is the great sense of accomplishment upon solving each puzzle. Obviously this is the case for most puzzle games but watching your awesome contraptions manhandle the blocks into submission in an elegant symphony of cleverly planned motion and manipulation of your own design is immensely satisfying, far more so than most puzzlers I have played

If you enjoy giving the ol' grey matter a good workout then don't hesitate to buy this game, it's an absolute joy.

19757590.review:
Infinifactory is a very open-ended puzzle game. You are presented with a bunch of input parts, and it's up to you to move and weld them in order to match them to the desired output. The factory that you put together to accomplish this purpose needs to synchronize the movement of all these individual pieces such that they interact cleanly, and don't accidentally push a piece one tile off and suddenly you have a massive traffic jam. Unlike some puzzle games, you're not stuck bashing your head trying to find the one and only solution - you're finding out how to make your own solution work.

For those who have played SpaceChem, you'll be right at home with these concepts. For those that haven't, I highly recommend you try the free demo for SpaceChem and see how you like that.

I find the difficulty in Infinifactory to be much more forgiving than in SpaceChem. You will never run out of room to come up with your solution - you have all the room in the world to make your solution as inelegant and bulky as possible if that's what it takes to make it work. Of course, the major appeal is still optimization. There are 3 categories to optimize for - complete the desired output in as little runtime as possible, use the least amount of vertical real estate, or use as few factory blocks as possible. The beauty of those optimized solutions is really what gives a great feeling of accomplishment to the players.

As detailed, the gameplay is extremely solid. The engine runs and loads smooth - there is nothing in the way of getting to the gameplay. There's a goofy story that entertains some, doesn't detract from the gameplay at all, but I would hardly consider it to be a major draw of the game. Graphics, sound, and music are all decent (music is a definite downgrade from SpaceChem).

19561660.review:
I’ll start the review this way: Infinifactory is up to now (Dec 2015) my favourite game all times. So this review might be a bit biased, but I’ll try to be as objective as I can.

Ok, first off: what is Infinifactory?

In Infinifactory, you build a factory out of blocks around input blocks, which you combine, wield and modify in order to obtain the output block (or structure) that you have to move to the output pad. This description doesn’t give justice to the game, I think other Steam reviews are way better at explaining the core of the game, but I’ll expand on more detailed elements of the game.

Infinifactory is better described as a [i]puzzle game[/i], because of the way the game is structured: you have a problem, and you have to provide a solution to it. But it is a [i]puzzle game[/i] in a way you have never seen before (at least if you didn’t play another Zachtronic game, such as [i]SpaceChem[/i] or [i]TIS-100[/i]). In the sense that you don’t have a unique, inelastic solution that you have to figure out by trial and error or logic: you build your factory from the ground up, with as much (if not more) freedom as if you were playing Minecraft, but with only functional blocks. This is why I love this game so much: each puzzle have literally a near infinite ways to be solved, and each solutions has its flaws and advantages. You can strive for the most elegant factory, or maybe you want something compact and minimize the footprint count, possibly, you can go for optimisation, or you just want to get done with the puzzle and unlock the next one. Each one of those building style will lead to drastically different factories and unique dynamic problems and challenges that you create for yourself, because you are masochistic and want to be higher ranked on the leaderboard.

Many people compare this game to programming, because the way problems happens and how you solve them is comparable to programming. As you progress into the game, you’ll have to remember technics that you learned on easier puzzles and use them in combination with other new technics, or adapt them to the new terrain and the new parts you are presented with.

When you build a factory, you can test it with the “play” button and easily figure out where your factory goes wrong (if it goes wrong, which it will, unless you are the incarnation of God on earth) because the game mechanics are based on 3D space and very simple predictable physics. It leads to you being able to judge what happens in the factory and build it based on your visual representation of what could happen.

Ok, now I won’t talk too much about the rest of the game, because the puzzles are where the meat and body of the game lies. In terms of graphics, it is good enough to be pleasing to the eye. In terms of story, it is good enough and minimalistic enough to not be distracting, and the music is soothing. All of that is the perfect storm to build a calm atmosphere which let you focus on the puzzles and building your factory 100% without losing your mind or being annoyed at all. Which is probably what puts this game over the top for me.

There is Workshop support: that means you can download custom puzzles made by other people and solve them in your way. There is some really good ones, and it would be a shame to miss on them. You can also build your own maps with the in-game map editor. This one is basically a Minecraft on steroid, since the game style is voxel based, so it is easy enough, once you get how to reach your favourite blocks, to build your own puzzles.

So why is this game so little popular? My guess is on the price tag: it seems a lot for an “indie” game, and people just don’t buy it. But look at my playtime, I have played Infinifactory for about 67 hours. The game is ridiculously great and has a lot of content, without for the least being repetitive or padded. There is about ten minutes of cutscence grand total, which means 99% of your playtime will be enjoying the game, and that’s without counting when you are thinking of the game not logged in, because you just thought of that cool new way of solving a puzzle in the bus or at work.

So here you have it, let yourself be convinced by this review, say goodbye to your 25 bucks and say hello to 60 hours of untold fun!

19497097.review:
I should've made a review for Infinifactory some time back but I kept putting the time off, waiting for the time when I could make a review worthy of such a fantastic game.  I fear I will never be able to do the game justice, so here goes with a short review as ideas simply pop into my head!

As you can notice from my first parapgraph I think extremely highly of Infinifactory.  For some time I was searching for a puzzle game with great replayability.  I heard about and played Spacechem, which is an impossible game not to mention when reviewing Infinifactory.  Both are developed by Zachtronics and both employ identical mechanic, but Spacechem is in 2D and Infinifactory is 3D.

The essence of the game is to take some materials as an input and manipulate them via building a machine/factory from different types of blocks to conform to the required output.  So you may have to rotate and weld two different types of blocks together or receive a broken item, remove the broken parts and replace them with good parts.  The variety of puzzles is very good and you don't feel like you're repeating the same processes during your progression.

The beauty of both games is that each puzzle can be solved in maybe an infinite variety of ways, so once you have made a solution you can go back and attempt to streamline various factors of your machine : footprint, cycles and blocks used.  Very similar to engineering projects in the real world!  

Hopefully some of your friendlist will also play the game as in game leaderboards are included for each puzzle to further the replayability.  There are slots to save three of your machines for each of the puzzles, so you can purpose build a machine for each of the scoring criteria e.g focus one machine solely on having the smallet footprint possible even if it is at the expense of being less efficient and having an increased cycle count.

I'm approaching 60 hours into the game and I am half-way through the second campaign of the two.  I've gone back and fine-tuned a few of my older machines and completed a couple of the community made puzzles.  There are literally hours and hours of gameplay available.  I'm generally not a "sandbox" type of guy either so Zachtronics have definietly managed to include the magic ingredient with this one.

A lovely feature of the game is to be able to export animated gifs from a static camera point of your working machine, which will loop infinitely.  It can be very satisfying to construct a particulaly nice process within your factory and watch it loop over-and-over.

The game has a slightly comedic and quirky story that holds the levels together and they progress in difficulty at a nice rate.  The levels get a bit easier when you start the second campaign and then begin to ramp up again!  There are some tough levels which may put off a few people that don't enjoy a mental challenge.  I found myself trying to solve some of the puzzles in my head whilst at work!!

This is one of my favourite games of 2015 so the question of whether I recommend it is not a tough one at all!!  It's easily worth the full price, I bought the game in a sale and feel a little ashamed for doing so!

Recipe for an Amazing Logic Puzzler: 

Pour 1 part SpaceChem into a Minecraft crust, top with Portal, and lightly season with Stanley Parable.  Bake in Early Access.  Consume (I lie - it consumes you).  Sublime.

Infinifactory ist eines der anspruchvollsten und kniffligsten Knobelspiele die ich bisher spielen durfte. Selbst, das schon recht komplexe, SpaceChem kann da nur noch weinend bei zuschauen, wie ich eine Fabrikationskette nach der andere zusammen schustere und einen Fehldruchlauf nach dem anderen produziere. Aber jeder Fehler im System fordert mich heraus diesen aufzuspüren und zu eliminieren; nur um mich mit einem fragenden Blick dem nächsten vermurksten Objekt hinterher winken zu lassen.

Was Zachtronics hier zusammengebastelt hat ist eine wahre Wunderwaffe um den Gehirnzellen mal richtig einzuheizen. Erstaunlich ist vor allem die Minimalistik mit der das Spiel auskommt. Nicht nur das die Grafik nicht gerade eine Augenweide ist und der nette, aber doch recht belanglose Soundtrack, zu monoton wummernden Maschinen leise im Hintergrund vor sich hindudelt; nein, es ist auch die Minimalistik im Spieldesign die von der ersten Sekunde an  fasziniert. Mit sehr wenigen Bauteilen, wobei die Limitierung hier nicht auf der Anzahl sondern auf der Auswahl liegt, soll ich ein Objekt erstellen, welches auf dem ersten Blick mit den gegebenen Mitteln unmöglich zu bauen ist.

Um das etwas genauer zu veranschaulichen zitiere ich hier einiger meiner Gedankengänge:

"Wie zur Hölle soll das gehen?" 

"Wo ist das scheiß Teil mit dem ich die Steine nach oben drücken kann?"

"Das ist unmöglich!"

"Ah, hm...."

"Ich könnte ja das mal auspro...."

"Ah, das könnte klappen..."

"Hm, shit. Da stimmt irgendwas nicht..."

"Vielleicht könnte ich die Steine ja...."

"Das sieht schon besser aus."

"Warum klappt das nicht?"

"Ich glaub meine Idee ist scheiße."

"Also nochmal von vorne..."

Und so fängt Infinitifactory jeden Problemlöser, Puzzler, Hobbyingenieur, Steinchenstappler und Tüfftler in einem Sog von Gedanken, absurden Einfällen und noch absurderen Lösungsstrategien, um mich am Ende mit dem wohligen Gefühl von "absoluter Genialität" und "geistiger Unerreichbarkeit" zu belohnen.

19237503.review:
I love me that Infinifactory. Its a sweet premise: Design the factory that machines the goods, and does them perfect again and again. You get a real sense of process and possibility, coming up with an A.) succesful and B.) efficient conveyer belt and fusing and manipulating path to achieve this. I wish more games could offer an emotive, plot-logical place of real, creative problem solving. It seems alien invaders like Vogons have kidnapped you and many others. You are crowd-sourced for the automated, efficient assembly of machinery, perhaps for the invasion of your own planet. It bares some similarities to this project, harnessing the human brain for a problem computers can't figure out: http://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2011/09/19/pc-gamers-save-the-world-a-bit/

You encounter the remains and optionally the audiologs of the failed characters left behind on most jobs. Once the cat is out of the bag they seem mostly to only be able to add texture to the story, but its a great story anyway.

Playing it, I use parts of my brain that are hard to tap. The puzzle game genre doesn't otherwise offer this kind of thorough, creative satisfaction. When learnt your creations can really come alive, consuming and outputting. Its like a language, like you've absorbed some spirit of programming by stealth. I think the design is splendid on all the levels, and when I think of the choices made to make such complexity intuitive and inviting it seems genius. Its so unlike the many degrading, addictive games that tempt us to distraction and numbness. I don't regret time spent with Infinifactory, and Its not like having my head buried in the sand, rather I come away feeling somehow better equipped to deal with life's problems. 

This opens the door of gaming for so much more, and at the same time as this innovation its definitely a game in the mechanical sense of a voluntary ruleset, manifestly challenging, that you struggle to perform better in, like a living parable. Unlike some missed opportunities nowadays which seem to dismiss this element as beneath them, or just not them (unworried by the essential concept of false advertising). Its something of a masterclass in that regard. 

I imagine it could be an amazing layer or part of the loop in something larger. Civ or Eve or Besieged or Kerbal Space Program or PlanetSide 2 or even Minecraft. Though I know its rude to state such things, crafting everywhere else seems really lacklustre, pithy and abstract now. This would have to be late game, jetpack-fuelled crafting in most settings, but my god! But then I think this with some action stage would EAT MY LIFE. As it stands, and if what you've gathered appeals, its a great investment. Well executed product too, for instance making resolution and graphics adjustments is so immediate and smooth and uncrashy it puts many big releases to shame.

See youtube for various super-efficient solutions to aspire to.

18830149.review:
Another remarkable release from Zachtronics!

Puzzle games come in many different forms nowadays, and they make you think in different ways. The part that I love about Infinifactory is that I can imagine, in my head, the parts of the output contraption coming together in a certain way, and then eventually getting all the movements timed and positioned correctly to make it happen. Or whatever gets the job done.

On the more difficult puzzles, the magnitude of what is required by the puzzle can make solving it take over an hour, easily. There is a certain threshold of patience, that if you can commit enough time and thought to that problem, you should be able to get it done after a while. Once you get the mechanics of the game down it's just a matter of that. I find that sometimes I am in that mood, and I'll solve a couple more problems, but most of the time it's hard to get motivated to solve some of those problems.

The game doesn't require you to solve every problem as you progress, however, so it's a blast as you're first going through it. I think that's a sufficient offset to the inherent difficulty of Infinifactory that I'll recommend this to the puzzlers out there. Due to the spacial nature of the game, if you like manipulating things in 3D, this is much more likely to arouse your interest. Of all the Zachtronics releases, I feel like this is probably the most accessible.

18254280.review:
This game is basically a 3-dimensional version of SpaceChem, where you have to construct large factories of conveyor belts and welders to build objects (like chairs) out of cubes. A lot of the annoying parts of SpaceChem have been stripped out -- the controls are much smoother now, and the silly interface of arrows and reactors is completely gone. If you like engineering games or the concept of SpaceChem, even if you didn't like SpaceChem, you'd enjoy this one.

The game does a great job building in complexity over time. A few levels feel like you're just doing the same thing over again, but I was impressed with how many levels presented a new concept, given the simplicity of what you're doing. Nor did anything get too hard, too fast; each new element added had tons of use cases, and each puzzle usually explored one of these use cases to the fullest possible extent. I felt like an expert at the end of the game, and levels that had taken me a while initially turned out to be really easy when I went back to them.

After a while, there's seemingly not much that can be added to the game other than asking you to build ever greater and more complex structures out of the cubes you're given. Thankfully, the game stops just short of getting boring, then gives you a lot of new toys to play with (via the DLC) and a bunch of difficult puzzles, then gracefully bows out. It's free, so it feels like a warm "Thank you so much for playing -- play these if you still want stuff to do". The DLC feels pretty tedious (especially the laser levels), but even that's something I might appreciate in a few months if I ever want to play again.

The achievements are exactly how achievements should be -- not too annoying, but requiring you to play a little bit creatively to get. The game took me about 12 hours to beat, but it was so much fun and I'm honestly glad it didn't drag on longer than it should have. Even if the main game doesn't scratch your engineering itch, there's like 20 more hours of extra content.

17975524.review:
This ranks alongside Spacechem as one of my all time favorite games. Challenging puzzles, engaging story, overall a well-oiled and ingeniously-designed game. Well worth the money for programming/engineering types and anyone who enjoyed Spacechem.

Gameplay
Pretty straightforward. Given parts, build a factory which assembles the parts into a final product. New tools are introduced one at a time, and there is just enough help given to the player to get them going. Obstacles and pitfalls arise naturally forcing the player to think of creative workarounds. I found the final puzzles very challenging, but neither frustrating nor insurmountable. Solving the finale was pretty satisfying!

Story
Unlike Spacechem, whose story was as cold and unforgiving as space, Infinifactory's storyline includes some subtle humor, as well as voice acting and interaction with physical characters. To me, the introduction of humor was a bit awkward at first, especially since it still retained elements of the same grim tone as Spacechem, but it was easy to get used to. Overall, the story branches out in tone rather well, and remains in the background and never distracts.

Other
The achievements and the workshop provide some extra challenges, and the nature of the game makes it very suitable for user-created puzzles. Gotta make my own soon...

Un muy buen juego de puzzles, con muchos niveles y muy adictivo. 

Tu objetivo en cada nivel es el de crear pequeñas fábricas capaces de ensamblar lo que te indiquen. Estas fabricas estan compuestas diversos bloques, cada uno con una función distinta, como cintas transportadoras, soldadores, sensores, actuadores, ect. (La satisfacción que provoca ver tu propia fábrica funcionando es indescriptible).

Este juego además tiene una historia por debajo que completa la ambientación y da sentido a todo lo que construyes. La mezcla de seriedad y humor es perfecta.

Los puzzles tienen la particularidad de que gozan de una solución abierta, es decir, según tu forma de pensar tu solución será distinta. Tras acabar un nivel se muestra como encaja tu solución con la del resto de personas comparandola en velocidad, espacio usado y bloques usados.

Respecto a la dificultad, los primeros niveles no son complejos y ayudan a familiarizarte con el entorno y las mecánicas, a partir de ese punto la dificultad aumenta progresivamente, pero sin llegar a ser imposibles.

Por último, destacar el aspecto visual y la banda sonora. Para mi increibles, los escenarios son preciosos y la musica te ayuda a concentrarte a la vez que concuerda con el escenario.

TL;DR - Si te gustó Spacechem, ves programas como "Así se hace" o te molan los sistemas de producción de las fábricas este juego te va a encantar.

购此游戏一年有余，也该认真写点东西了。

　解谜游戏，或长于剧情，或长于玩法，《无限工厂》（INFINIFACTORY）显然为后者。
　如果说走迷宫算解谜游戏的话，多数解谜游戏其实并无两样，只不过是“迷宫”更大、更复杂而已。这些游戏，无非就是让玩家找到作者设计好的路线，再顺着路走到终点。也就是说，多数解谜游戏是有标准答案的，玩家在游玩过程中并没有新的创造，只是将作者推倒的积木一个个搭起来，十分死板。
　《无限工厂》则与之不同。正如其名，游戏提供了多种工具方块，用这些方块能产生无限的组合，规则简单，而变化无穷，这点和MC很像。同样是搭一个立体图形，你可以把小方块一层层叠起来，也可以叠成一个大方块再削掉多余的部分。给你一个板子去染色，你可以让它在印刷器前做蛇形运动，也可以把版子切成小块，分别染色，再焊成一个整体（就是很浪费）。这款游戏可以让你发挥奇思妙想、脑洞大开，也能让你在游玩之余，看到创意工坊中各路大神的作品时，发出“还能这样玩”的赞叹。
　总之，若想体验独特而自由的解谜游戏，《无限工厂》值得一试。

Ps:老菊都弃坑了，我肯定比他强！

17804189.review:
Infinifactory is the best puzzle game I've ever played. It takes something truly compelling for me to spend hours, sometimes days at the end, perfecting a single puzzle, and yet I have never felt frustrated.  This is a game that truly earns the description 'engaging.' 

Everything that happens in this game is because you made it, and you need to have your brain firing on all cylinders to make it through. But fear not, any new players considering this game: the mechanics are easy to approach and you'll be hooked in no time.  Players who have enjoyed any other game by Zachtronics (like Spacechem or TIS-100) or who like similar games with similar mechanics (Factorio, Big Pharma,  even the city-builder games by Impressions) will absolutely love Infinifactory, but I think anyone willing to giving Infinifactory a chance will love it too.

In this quick review, I'll discuss the gameplay of Infinifactory, it's aesthetics, and try to answer why I've been unable to put this game down. 

The gameplay is simple: from a certain point at the start of each stage, a series of inputs regularly pop out a component-usually a single box, but other times a more complex shape.  From there, the goal is to simply combine these inputs to meet at the output area, and repeat this ten times.  The player has a number of tools at their disposal, from simple conveyor belts and welders, to parts that push and destroy.  With these parts, all sorts of advanced operations may be performed- advanced techniques even allow players to build 'circuits' from these simple parts.  A later level may resemble a factory made by a mad scientist, full of pipes and blocks, with piecies whirring and whizzing by, only just avoiding disaster.

Infinifactory has pleasing visuals, notable for its sturdy blocks and the orange and blue color scheme of its factory parts.  The environemnts are colorful, vidid, and distinctly not of this world. The screen shots do a better job describing what it looks like than I can, but as you can see, there are a great number pleasant and varied stages, and for the most part, there feels like a good variety of factory components, too. 

There is an interesting story being told, usually through voice logs and a handful of scripted sequences that set the stage for Infinifactory's otherworldly visuals. In many puzzle games, even those that do try to tell a story, the gameplay has no relation to the story. Here, there's a [i]reason[/i] why you're building things- and you may not exactly be doing it of your own free will. The story's tone is quirky, with a grinning undercurrent of black humor.  There are a few twists and turns along the way that delighted me.  I found that a nicely written story like this helped ground the events and kept me interested.

Puzzles in this game have a wonderful quality where the final output seems simple, yet constructing it from its individual components can be deceptively challenging.  There's a smooth difficulty curve, with tools introduced gradually and new techniques being learned organically as more challenging puzzles are introduced. By the time I'd beaten the game, I found that I could go back to puzzles that took me 90 minutes to solve and beat them in 20 minutes, with a much better score as well.  

At the end of each puzzle, the player is ranked according to three criteria: how fast the puzzle was, how many blocks it took to build, and how much space it took up.  I like the way that this scoring encouraged me, because it was rare that I hadn't done well in at least one category.  This system encourages different styles of play-those who (like me) enjoy sprawling, messy solutions that strive to be as fast as possible, or those who favor a more restrained, elegant design.  

The game comes with a capable level editor that's integrated into the Steam Workshop. Already, tons of user-made levels are available for play. In my experience, though, few have stacked up against the levels in the campaign.  Most are based around gimmicks or some other novel use of the mechanics.  Sometimes this is successful, but overall I haven't found it as satisfying. That said, I can't claim to have explored the workshop throughly, or to have attempted to create any levels of my own.

The true joy in this game comes from the sense of owning each solution you make. There's no single way to solve each puzzle-there are hundreds.  After completing a particularly challenging puzzle, I've often looked up how others have solved theirs- not once has my solution resembled someone else's. 

I never had the feeling, like I often do with puzzle games, that I was fighting with the developer to find the 'right' way to solve the problem.  Instead, Infinifactory simply gives its players a handful of tools and asks, "Why don't you build something interesting?"

I think it's the mark of a great puzzle game that I have enjoyed my failures as much as my successes.  I have looked back at puzzles that took me hours to solve, and even though the final result was a swollen, creaky machine, I can remember all the hurdles and struggles it took for me to create my solution and think, "Yeah, I built that."

17791958.review:
Another sublime "programming" game from the mad genius who brought us SpaceChem. This time you've been kidnapped by the alien overlords who have set you to building them factories.

Basically, you get given one or more "inputs" (usually single blocks of different types) and (usually) one "output" that's built from those blocks. You have to build a production line out of conveyer belts, welders, pistons, sensors, etc that can repeatedly turn the ipnuts into the outputs. All this is done in a Minecraft-like world of cubes (and the guy who created this game also created Infiniminer, which was a major inspiration for Minecraft).

Once you've solved the puzzle, you get three little graphs that show you how your solution compares to the solutions of all the other players in terms of how quickly it produces the required output, how many blocks you used, and how much space it took up. Then (if you're like me) comes the fun part: optimize, optimize, optimize, and try to get the best possible score in each of the metrics (most likely with three different solutions). The great thing about the graphs is that because nobody can see anyone else's scores, there's no real incentive for anyone to cheat, and because it doesn't show exact scores, You can aim for the slightly softer target of the top score bracket rather than being tormeted byt that one guy who has an insanely good score...

My new favourite pure puzzle game.

17696776.review:
Infinifactory est un jeu fou qui rend fou. Sous réserve bien sûr de ne pas être hermétique à son concept de mixeur de cerveau, Infinifactory vous aspire littéralement corps et âme.
Votre corps tout d’abord, car physiquement vous allez passer des heures à vous retourner le cerveau devant votre écran pour régler au poil de fesse vos timings afin que votre chaine de production tourne rond.
Votre âme enfin, car en cas d’arrêt d’une session de jeu (soit parce que vous avez comme tout le monde une vie en dehors de votre usine virtuelle, soit parce que vous allez forcément baisser les bras à un moment), votre cerveau va continuer à tourner en boucle sur votre problème jusqu’à ce que, ne tenant plus, vous retourniez rapidement essayer la projection mentale de ce que vous pensez être la solution.

Sous ses airs faussement simplistes de grosse boite de LEGO, Infinifactory est pour faire simple un langage de programmation purement visuel, que tous les profs d’automatisme industriel se devraient d’intégrer à leur formation.
Certes, on pestera parfois que telle pièce n’existe pas alors qu’il nous semblerait tellement évident qu’elle nous soit fourni de base. Un peu comme avec les LEGO en fait, où après 15 minutes de montage de notre nouvelle création, on se rendait compte que la brique qui nous aurait comblés de joie n’existe pas…

Pour finir, la mise en scène de l’aventure (oui, oui, l’auteur a même réussi à intégrer une histoire !) tient la route, et prête même à rire de temps à autre tellement les personnages qui nous entourent sont parfois grand-guignol.

Un jeu hautement addictif et intelligent qui a la bonté de nous faire croire que nous le sommes également… intelligents.

Un jeu vraiment passionnant proposant des challenges de difficulté variables (toutefois moins relevés que SpaceChem du même auteur), mais permet d'y répondre de diverses manières.

Infinifactory donne en effet une grande liberté dans la manière d'arriver au but. On est poussé à trouver une solution plus rapide, plus performante, moins consommatrice de blocs, mais le jeu nous demande surtout d'aller au bout de nos idées. 

C'est assez rare qu'une idée initiale n'aboutisse pas, mais la méthode la moins académique aboutira à une vraie usine à gaz... mais qui fonctionne tout de même. Car le vrai plaisir de ce jeu, c'est de souffrir, de repenser, modeler, et voir notre propre création tourner.

Ce que l'on pourrait reprocher? Peut-être des graphismes un peu austères même si très lisibles et suffisants, et une option pour déplacer des blocs déjà créés plutôt qu'avoir à les détruire pour les recréer. Mais ce sont des détails...

Pour finir, un jeu fidèle aux autres productions Zachtronics: interface limpide, gameplay extrêmement simple, ambiance réussie, courbe d'apprentissage maîtrisée et puzzles intéressant. Le jeu se paie même le luxe d'avoir un scénario.

17400427.review:
Infinifactory is very different from almost any other puzzle game you can find. Primarily, it is not a game about finding the goal: what you start with, and what you end with, are both given to you. It is up to the player to turn the input into the output, and to do so, they must design a machine to solve the level. It is not a game about building things; in a very abstract way, it is a game about programming. Just like SpaceChem and TIS-100. And a few Flash games, mostly made by the Zachtronics themselves. It's a very barren market; you owe it to yourself to play at least one of them, if you like puzzles. And Infinifactory is, by far, the easiest to recommend.

"Like SpaceChem, but 3D" is not an inaccurate description. It is very much about taking a collection of parts, each with a very simple job (move a block, turn a block, detect a block) and stringing them together to make outputs. But Infinifactory demonstrates a key difference to SpaceChem: it's not as aggressively difficult. It is impossible to understate just how difficult SpaceChem becomes at the later levels; so difficult, that it's hard to even find enjoyment from the frustration. And you can take the developer's word for it: in the postmortem, Zach Barth described SpaceChem as having "an oppressive 40+ hour difficulty curve that only 2 percent of players reach the end of."

Infinifactory manages to provide all the satisfaction of SpaceChem, without the progress-denying difficulty. And it is not due to a lack of difficult levels; the game introduces many new mechanics at a regular rate, and it makes use of all of them. The more forgiving difficulty comes as a result of more subtle design choices; there's the obvious increase in player options by having a third dimension, but Infinifactory also never forces the player into a confined space. The actual construction zone in SpaceChem was always tiny, but you are never at a loss for space in Infinifactory. Combined with having a lot more tools, this means the player can solve any level using a vast number of approaches, and will almost certainly be able to make that method work if they keep at it. I would posit this as a very good thing.

The story of the game is dissimilar to SpaceChem and TIS-100 in that it is surprisingly straightforward. Both of their other games dabble in a Lovecraftian-esque sense of mystique, stories that tease you with the unknown, often even making the player uncomfortable even as they desperately want to have the answers. Infinifactory's story has its twists, but I must say I missed the sense of discovery their other games have provided; I feel that has always paired very well with the gameplay.

The last levels of the game were far more disappointing (minor spoilers to follow). The difficulty curve of the endgame is very well done; each of the final areas are easily distinguished by their mechanics alone. However, this breaks down at the second to last level. This level introduces an entirely new mechanic: instead of turning inputs into outputs, you have to build a machine to control the firing of weapons, and target your enemies. At the same time, it introduces a new block - a toggle, to allow you to control the machine in real time. The level itself is also fairly difficult, with failure always only a few seconds away. To throw all of these new mechanics at the player at once, and require such aptitude from them, is quite off-putting; while I did enjoy most of the boss levels in SpaceChem, I felt this was poorly executed. The final level itself was also incredibly underwhelming. Not that it was easy - it's an alright final level - but it was a bit disappointing that none of the mechanics introduced towards the end of the game were actually implemented. I believe the final level would have been much more interesting if the inputs were organized in a more forgiving way, and all the mechanics such as paints and metal were somehow implemented in it.

Another, much broader issue is the implementation of the Steam Workshop. Namely, there is no in-game way to really interact with a level, other than just playing it. It would mean a lot if the game would offer for you to rate/comment on a level after you've played it - while you can always open it up in your browser, you clearly can't expect others to do that, and most of the community levels for Infinifactory have no ratings or comments. The real issue is that browsing for levels is affected by this lack of information, and the game itself does not encourage anyone to provide it.

But that's the last two levels out of a game containing a few dozen. Those two paragraphs basically contain all of my complaints for the game, but I can't fit all of my praise into this entire review. Seriously, Infinifactory is great, you should buy it.

17148949.review:
Infinifactory does this thing I love. It makes you earn your enjoyment of it. 

You load up your next task and take a look at what you'll need to produce and what materials you'll have to produce it with. Immediately, some ideas start popping and you think, "Okay, I know what to do." Ten minutes later, everything's wrong and you realize you were being naive. But you keep building and trying things because that's just who you are. An hour later, things start to click. You still feel dumb as bricks but you're at least smarter than you were ten minutes ago. Then, long after you began, you have a working production facility. You are a genius. The smartest of the smart. Nothing can bring you down from this high.

Then you get to see how your solution rates against everyone else who's finished that same factory and it turns out you're actually pretty much middle-of-the-road. But maybe you can go back and adjust some things and score better? Or maybe you've learned some things and maybe your vision and clarity has leveled up and just by starting fresh you can shave your score by half?

Whatever the case, you have had a blast. You've been challenged for the first time in who knows how long. You've had fun and by all the things that you might even consider swearing on, you've earned that fun.
____

SpaceChem is one of my favourite puzzle games of all time. I adore its design and its open-ended puzzles. I was interested in Infinifactory because I liked SpaceChem. I was also skeptical. I didn't like the idea of doing puzzles in a 3D space. I didn't like the aesthetic. I didn't like the whole factory concept. 

I needn't have worried. Infinifactory is actually probably better than SpaceChem. Which hurts me to say. But it doesn't hurt too much because I'm busy having tons of fun.

An excellent puzzle game in which you create factories using an assortment of tools like conveyors, welders, pushers and sensors to build all sort of things for the alien race that abducted you. The plot is actually pretty good and relatively humorous and helps keep you motivated to complete the more challenging puzzles, but a lot of it can be ignored if you are only interested in the puzzles. There is a pretty decent amount of variety in the puzzles and they take place in several different locations, and there's also the occasional unique element in a puzzle that you wont see in other ones, which all helps keep things fresh so you are frequently faced with new things to discover. There's a fair bit of replayability if you are interested in competing with friends to get the best scores on a puzzle or are just interested in optimizing them to be faster, smaller, or use fewer blocks.

I absolutely recommend this to anyone interested in a puzzle game, it's a lot of fun and just the right amount of challenging.

17092500.review:
Did you play SpaceChem? Did you like it? Just skip the rest of this review and buy Infinifactory now, you can thank me later.

Everybody else: this is a game for programmers, engineers, puzzle addicts, and generally anybody who enjoys using logic to solve, or create, problems. Kidnapped by a Vogon-like race of aliens, you will be forced to create machines that automatically assemble (and sometimes disassemble) an increasingly complex variety of objects. Your tools are a collection of cube-shaped building blocks - conveyors, welders, pistons, sensors, etc. - of which you have an infinite supply. There are no time limits or resource limits, just a set of inputs and a target output. The feeling of satisfaction you get when one of your creations finally works the way it's supposed to is only matched by the feeling you get when you suddenly realize how to get it working even better; shaving a few cycles off your assembly time or eliminating a handful of extraneous blocks. And if, sorry, *when* you get frustrated, there's something oddly rewarding about deliberately monkey-wrenching the works and watching the garbage output pile up to the sky. In the end, you're free to settle for hackish stupid-but-it-works solutions, or to go full ASME and devise mechanical logic gates and suchlike to produce fine-tuned precision assembly lines - each level has three "slots" for you to work in, so you're free to copy over designs or work on alternative solutions without throwing away work you've already done. There's even a Steam achievement for creating exceptionally inefficient solutions, which is a nice touch.

The plot, such as it is, is mostly there for seasoning and is at first just dribbled out in the various atmospheric touches like your spartan quarters (containing only a bed, a food pellet dispenser, and a bathroom-like facility clearly designed by somebody who didn't know much about human anatomy, and didn't care to learn more) and the aliens' curious and misguided attempts to provide motivational rewards. Details start to emerge as you progress, mostly in recorded "failure logs" hidden throughout the levels, and finally things start to be spelled out in considerably more detail, after a plot twist which I guess I shouldn't give away here. There's humor, tragedy, and intrigue, all of which is really just a bonus as far as I'm concerned - like any good puzzle game, the puzzles themselves provide all the motivation needed to want to press on, and I found the difficulty curve to be just about perfect.

There's a few glitches in the version I'm currently playing - occasionally you'll fall through what appears to be solid ground, for example - but fortunately your character is equipped with a jetpack so this is merely an annoyance, and not really game-affecting. The graphics are simple and clean, and this should run fairly well even on low-end or outdated PCs. I should also mention the ability to automatically record looping GIFs of your creations, which is a nice touch.

This is definitely not for people who prefer their games to mostly consist of problems that are solved by shooting at them, but if the concept behind Infinifactory appeals to you at all, I can all but guarantee you're going to have a lot of fun here.

17091686.review:
It's straightforward.  The mechanics are simple.  The purpose is clear.  There's no confusion as to what you are expected to do and what tools you have to do it.  

It's diabolical.  The puzzles are sometimes bananas, requiring some pretty twisted logic and lateral thinking.  While you strive for a solution, there's a constant nagging feeling that sometimes your solution is just [i]inelegant[/i] and you need to do it better.

It's oddly darkly humorous.  There's a strange undercurrent of defiance against your alien overlords, from listening to the audio diaries of the project managers who came before you, from resenting the food pellets that drop into your cell when you complete sections of the game.

It's also gorgeous - not so much in graphics, which are perfectly adequate, but in the efficiency of the presentation.  No main menu.  No weird visual effects cluttering up the screen. No unnecessarily ostentatious setpieces.  No splash screen! On load, the game drops you right into where you left, so you can literally load the game and get building.  There's a gorgeousness to seeing your machine, your factory do its work, and the satisfaction that comes with it makes the effort all the more worth it.

It's one of the most interesting puzzle games I've ever played, and I'm enjoying it hugely despite not being great at coming up with particularly creative solutions.

This is an excellent puzzle game that provides a very accessible visual analogy to writing a computer program (something I do for a living). The premise is that you are a human who has been kidnapped by a malevolent alien race. In each scenario you face, you are compelled by your new masters to design a factory process by piecing together machinery components about the size of minecraft blocks. You are given input blocks that spit out of magic holes at a pre-determined frequency. You are given a goal of what the end product of those input blocks should look like after rolling through your little factory. 
Often there are many different ways to skin the cat presented to you, some being more efficient then others. It's really neat to skim the forums and see all of the different ideas that people come up with to accomplish the same goal.
The game doesn't distract you with alot of filler. It's presentation is very straight forward and simple. The solutions you come up with probably won't be, which is alot of the fun.
This is a solid, fun game that makes you think and create. It's also not all that expensive. Definately recommend it.

16901221.review:
I enjoyed SpaceChem in the sense that I enjoyed the emotional pain of creating an incredibly complex "machine" only to discover that it reversed something somewhere along the path and it was easier to delete and start over with the lessons learnt than to try and patch in a fix -- which would inevitably work but break something else (lesson?). Infinifactory is WAY more fun than SpaceChem. I'm not sure whether to attribute that to its satisfying 3D Minecraftesque environment, or the story with all its food nuggets, VHS tapes, and trucker hats, or the wide variety of blocks that such an environment allows. Really, it's all of the above and more. Here is a game in which the developers applied all that experience and feedback from SpaceChem and applied it in a way that manages to be equal parts difficult, frustrating (in a good way), fun, funny, and oh-so-deeply satisfying. 

Without ruining everything, I'll say I came to what I thought was the final "mission" of the game and found it an appropriately complex and large build that took a good amount of thought and planning. As I watched the last completed unit pass into what we'll call the recepticle, I thought "this was money well spent, and I'm going to go through and optimize all my earlier builds. Moreover, this was so good that I'm going to go write my first Steam review to send thanks to the devs and recommendations to other logic gamers." That was my thought at that point in the game, and then I found out there's more. More compelling, more complex, and I figured I'd stop here, write that review, and only then get back to the next build.

I've already spent a lot of extra time rebuilding machines that passed but didn't satisfy me, satisfy in the sense that maybe they wasted blocks that could have been put to better use, or managed to build the prescribed number of objects but would have broken had it been asked to cycle endlessly (just one there) without any bugs. Feels good to come away with instant feedback that tells you that you've built something as efficiently as anyone else has been able. Many won't want to strive for that type of perfection, and the truth is that I won't for all the puzzles, but the point is that they've produced an environment and the tools that make you enjoy what would under normal circumstances be a chore and not a game.

i've only put a few hours into this game so far, and i feel as though i'm probably only starting to scratch the surface on it's complexity, but at this point, i am having an absolute blast with it!

the game works precisely as displayed in the trailer: you are given x inputs, told to produce y output, and you have to figure out how to get y from x using the factory machinery tools provided to you. These tools include conveyor belts, pistons, sensors, welders, and more. It becomes very quickly apparent with any seemingly easy puzzle, that the deceptively simple systems the game provides you can and must be used to created increasingly complex and synergistic structures, as you create more and more intricate outputs. 

The game very thoroughly challenges your problem-solving skills, spatial and mechanical awareness, and logical abilities.  I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a truly unique, engaging, and challenging puzzle game.

Another game from Zachtronics that I cannot recommend enough. Many people are calling it "SpaceChem in 3d" which is a fair description, but doesn't really capture the fun of finally guiding your blocks through twists and turns to get them synced up and in the right position at exactly the right time to have your construct output correctly.

The overarching storyline is a bit minimal, but the real fun is in solving the puzzles in new ways. There's that sense of accomplishment when you see your machine completing the task, especially when your results compare favorably with the global statistics. There are audio logs from previous solvers scattered throughout the levels which add to the world, but are not needed to enjoy the game.

As with SpaceChem, on occasion, I find some puzzles to be immediately obvious even at later levels, while others I sometimes have to think about for a while before a possible solution emerges. There are also some quirks of which control block takes precedence that you will have to work around and/or exploit to get the jobs finished.

Community created puzzles are available in the Steam Workshop, but prepare to be challenged by them. The community seems to pride themselves on devious puzzle crafting. 

Overall, one of the most fun games I have played all year.

My official game of the year for 2015!

This game is 3D Spacechem. For more details, please see my Spacechem review.

I still think Spacechem is the best puzzle game ever made. I haven't played enough of this to decide if this ursurps the puzzle game throne, but it looks like a good possibility so far.

These games are hard to describe and intimidating to watch without having played (especially Spacechem since its just a bunch of weird lines and symbols). The best way I can think to describe it is, think of programming a loop or a method. You know what the inputs and outputs need to be and you know a few other functions/methods that you can use to take the inputs and make the outputs. These games are all about designing a repeatable process that won't fail under a heavy load.

Besides the 3D, one of the main differentiators Infinifactory has is a humorous storyline that follows the "Show, don't tell" school of writing. I remember Spacechem being pretty wordy and not funny, but Infinifactory is the opposite!

Buy Infinifactory.

16815845.review:
Infinifactory is my favorite puzzle game I've played in a long while, maybe ever. It's all the programmy goodness of Spacechem (and Zach's earlier browser games) but in a beautiful 3D environment with some cool storytelling mixed in.

Infinifactory is a puzzle game, but different than what you may be used to in this genre. You're given a set of input blocks, and must maneuver, combine, and reconfigure these blocks to match a specific output on the other side of the map. It's incredibly open-ended in how this is accomplished, allowing for some brilliantly simple, or horrifyingly overly complicated solutions to the same problem.

Difficulty curve is nice and smooth, reaching a peak difficulty that will require some serious time and thinking to work through, but was never hard enough to get me to give up entirely. Adding a bunch of folks to your Steam friends to compare scores with adds an extra level of replayability by giving you the opportunity to optimize your solutions to get a few cycles under your buddies.

Infinifactory was further reviewed by myself and my good friend Gary in episode 38 of our podcast Check it Out, Comrade! Give it a listen!
